name: hydrogen compression, from low to medium pressure | hydrogen, gaseous, medium pressure, merchant | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/28383/documentation

This dataset represents the compression of hydrogen, gaseous, low pressure at 25 bar to medium pressure gaseous hydrogen at 200 bar. The pressure of 200 bar is recommended as the functional unit by the IEA Hydrogen Task 36 (Iribarren et al, 2018).;This dataset was recontextualised from the European dataset.;References:;A. Valente, D. Iribarren and J. Dufour (2021): Comparative life cycle sustainability assessment of renewable and conventional hydrogen. Science of The Total Environment, 756, 144132.;Iribarren, D., Valente, A., Dufour, J., 2018. IEA Hydrogen Task 36 – Life Cycle Sustainability Assessment of Hydrogen Energy Systems – Final Report. IEA Hydrogen, Bethesda.

This activity starts with hydrogen, gaseous, low pressure (25bar) at the factory gate. The dataset includes electricity to compress hydrogen and cooling water, and water release, for the intermediate cooling.

This activity ends with hydrogen, gaseous, medium pressure (200 bar) at the factory gate ready for further processing or transport.
category: D:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/35:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/352:Manufacture of gas; distribution of gaseous fuels through mains/3520:Manufacture of gas; distribution of gaseous fuels through mains

processDocumentation.technologyDescription: This dataset represents the compression of hydrogen, gaseous, low pressure at 25 bar to medium pressure at 200 bar.;The electricity needed for conversion was calculated based on literature.;Reference:;Antonini C., Treyer K., Streb A., van der Spek M., Bauer C., Mazzotti M. (2020): Hydrogen production from natural gas and biomethane with carbon capture and storage – A techno-environmental analysis, Sustainable Energy Fuels.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: This dataset has been copied from an original dataset covering the geography RER. The uncertainty has been adjusted accordingly.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
This dataset is based on literature data. The technology is representative for compressing hydrogen Globally and regionalised through the input feedstocks.

Reference:
Antonini C., Treyer K., Streb A., van der Spek M., Bauer C., Mazzotti M. (2020): Hydrogen production from natural gas and biomethane with carbon capture and storage - A techno-environmental analysis, Sustainable Energy Fuels.

flow.name: hydrogen, gaseous, medium pressure, merchant
flow.category: D:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/35:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/352:Manufacture of gas; distribution of gaseous fuels through mains/3520:Manufacture of gas; distribution of gaseous fuels through mains

exchanges.description:
Cooling for two-stage compression based on thermodynamic considerations for compression units with a 75% adiabatic efficiency: hydrogen, gaseous at 25 bar and 35 °C to hydrogen, gaseous at 200 bar and 25 °C. The two-stage intermediate compression and cooling is based on the work by Antonini et al. (2020)

References:
Antonini C., Treyer K., Streb A., van der Spek M., Bauer C., Mazzotti M. (2020): Hydrogen production from natural gas and biomethane with carbon capture and storage - A techno-environmental analysis, Sustainable Energy Fuels.

Electricity required to compress low pressure hydrogen to medium pressure hydrogen.
If hydrogen is produced by steam methane refomring, is assumed that the excess electricity from steam methane reforming is used to compress hydrogen to medium pressure. If hydrogen is produced from coal, the electricity required to compress hydrogen comes from the grid.

Based on Antonini C., Treyer K., Streb A., van der Spek M., Bauer C., Mazzotti M. (2020): Hydrogen production from natural gas and biomethane with carbon capture and storage – A techno-environmental analysis, Sustainable Energy Fuels.

exchanges.description: Calculated value based on literature values and expert opinion. See comments in the parametres' comment field.

Input of hydrogen.
In the United States, more than 95% of the hydrogen is produced by steam methane reforming and 5% from coal.

References:
IEA (2021): The Future of Hydrogen, available here: https://www.iea.org/reports/the-future-of-hydrogen.
